this.$debug
If debug is true, this will be the jQuery object for the visible rectangle.
We keep track of whether the tabs are hidden in this (internal) variable so we still have access to that information during the window’s unload event, when window.Tabs no longer exists.
The Tabs tab that represents the active tab in the active window.
this.bounds
The position and size of this Item, represented as a Rect.
get button(
   
){ return win.document.querySelector("#tabcandy-button"); }, } context.Toolbar
A getter that yields the toolbar button for direct manipulation.
this.container
The outermost DOM element that describes this item on screen.
this.currentTab
Keeps track of which Tabs tab we are currently on.
this.debug
When set to true, displays a rectangle on the screen that corresponds with bounds.
this.devMode
If true (set by an url parameter), adds extra features to the screen.
this.focused
Keeps track of whether Tab Candy is focused.
The Tabs tab that represents the tab candy tab.
this.isAnItem
Always true for Items
this.locked
Affects whether an item can be pushed, closed, renamed, etc
this.navBar
A reference to the Navbar, for manipulating the browser’s nav bar.
this.parent
The group that this item is a child of
How to deal when things go off the edge.
this.tabBar
A reference to the Tabbar, for manipulating the browser’s tab bar.
this.userSize
A Point that describes the last size specifically chosen by the user.
